trans-unit.target: Introduction

trans-unit.source: The fundamental requirements for deploying Windows Server Active Directory on Azure virtual machines differ very little from deploying it in on-premises virtual machines (and, to some extent, physical machines).
trans-unit.target: The fundamental requirements for deploying Windows Server Active Directory on Azure virtual machines differ very little from deploying it in on-premises virtual machines (and, to some extent, physical machines).

trans-unit.source: For example, in the case of Windows Server AD DS, if the domain controllers (DCs) that you deploy on Azure virtual machines are replicas in an existing on-premises corporate domain/forest, then the Azure deployment can largely be treated in the same way as you might treat any other additional Windows Server Active Directory site.
trans-unit.target: For example, in the case of Windows Server AD DS, if the domain controllers (DCs) that you deploy on Azure virtual machines are replicas in an existing on-premises corporate domain/forest, then the Azure deployment can largely be treated in the same way as you might treat any other additional Windows Server Active Directory site.

trans-unit.source: That is, subnets must be defined in Windows Server AD DS, a site created, the subnets linked to that site, and connected to other sites using appropriate site-links.
trans-unit.target: That is, subnets must be defined in Windows Server AD DS, a site created, the subnets linked to that site, and connected to other sites using appropriate site-links.

trans-unit.source: There are, however, some differences that are common to all Azure deployments and some that vary according to the specific deployment scenario.
trans-unit.target: There are, however, some differences that are common to all Azure deployments and some that vary according to the specific deployment scenario.

trans-unit.source: Two fundamental differences are outlined below:
trans-unit.target: Two fundamental differences are outlined below:

trans-unit.source: Azure virtual machines may need connectivity to the on-premises corporate network.
trans-unit.target: Azure virtual machines may need connectivity to the on-premises corporate network.

trans-unit.source: Connecting Azure virtual machines back to an on-premises corporate network requires Azure virtual network, which includes a site-to-site or site-to-point virtual private network (VPN) component able to seamlessly connect Azure virtual machines and on-premises machines.
trans-unit.target: Connecting Azure virtual machines back to an on-premises corporate network requires Azure virtual network, which includes a site-to-site or site-to-point virtual private network (VPN) component able to seamlessly connect Azure virtual machines and on-premises machines.

trans-unit.source: This VPN component could also enable on-premises domain member computers to access a Windows Server Active Directory domain whose domain controllers are hosted exclusively on Azure virtual machines.
trans-unit.target: This VPN component could also enable on-premises domain member computers to access a Windows Server Active Directory domain whose domain controllers are hosted exclusively on Azure virtual machines.

trans-unit.source: It is important to note, though, that if the VPN fails, authentication and other operations that depend on Windows Server Active Directory will also fail.
trans-unit.target: It is important to note, though, that if the VPN fails, authentication and other operations that depend on Windows Server Active Directory will also fail.

trans-unit.source: While users may be able to sign in using existing cached credentials, all peer-to-peer or client-to-server authentication attempts for which tickets have yet to be issued or have become stale will fail.
trans-unit.target: While users may be able to sign in using existing cached credentials, all peer-to-peer or client-to-server authentication attempts for which tickets have yet to be issued or have become stale will fail.

trans-unit.source: Terms and definitions
trans-unit.target: Terms and definitions

trans-unit.source: The following is a non-exhaustive list of terms for various Azure technologies which will be referenced in this article.
trans-unit.target: The following is a non-exhaustive list of terms for various Azure technologies which will be referenced in this article.

trans-unit.source: **Azure virtual machines**: The IaaS offering in Azure that allows customers to deploy VMs running nearly any traditionally on-premises server workload.
trans-unit.target: **Azure virtual machines**: The IaaS offering in Azure that allows customers to deploy VMs running nearly any traditionally on-premises server workload.

trans-unit.source: **Azure virtual network**: The networking service in Azure that lets customers create and manage virtual networks in Azure and securely link them to their own on-premises networking infrastructure by using a virtual private network (VPN).
trans-unit.target: **Azure virtual network**: The networking service in Azure that lets customers create and manage virtual networks in Azure and securely link them to their own on-premises networking infrastructure by using a virtual private network (VPN).

trans-unit.source: **Virtual IP address**: An internet-facing IP address that is not bound to a specific computer or network interface card.
trans-unit.target: **Virtual IP address**: An internet-facing IP address that is not bound to a specific computer or network interface card.

trans-unit.source: Cloud services are assigned a virtual IP address for receiving network traffic which is redirected to an Azure VM.
trans-unit.target: Cloud services are assigned a virtual IP address for receiving network traffic which is redirected to an Azure VM.

trans-unit.source: A virtual IP address is a property of a cloud-service which can contain one or more Azure virtual machines.
trans-unit.target: A virtual IP address is a property of a cloud-service which can contain one or more Azure virtual machines.

trans-unit.source: Also note that an Azure virtual network can contain one or more cloud-services.
trans-unit.target: Also note that an Azure virtual network can contain one or more cloud-services.

trans-unit.source: Virtual IP addresses provide native load-balancing capabilities.
trans-unit.target: Virtual IP addresses provide native load-balancing capabilities.

trans-unit.source: **Dynamic IP address**: This is the IP address that is internal only.
trans-unit.target: **Dynamic IP address**: This is the IP address that is internal only.

trans-unit.source: It should be configured as a static IP address (by using the Set-AzureStaticVNetIP cmdlet) for VMs that host the DC/DNS server roles.
trans-unit.target: It should be configured as a static IP address (by using the Set-AzureStaticVNetIP cmdlet) for VMs that host the DC/DNS server roles.

trans-unit.source: **Service healing**: The process in which Azure automatically returns a service to a running state again after it detects that the service has failed.
trans-unit.target: **Service healing**: The process in which Azure automatically returns a service to a running state again after it detects that the service has failed.

trans-unit.source: Service healing is one of the aspects of Azure that supports availability and resiliency.
trans-unit.target: Service healing is one of the aspects of Azure that supports availability and resiliency.

trans-unit.source: While unlikely, the result following a service healing incident for a DC running on a VM is similar to an unplanned reboot, but has a few side-effects:
trans-unit.target: While unlikely, the result following a service healing incident for a DC running on a VM is similar to an unplanned reboot, but has a few side-effects:

trans-unit.source: The virtual network adapter in the VM will change
trans-unit.target: The virtual network adapter in the VM will change

trans-unit.source: The MAC address of the virtual network adapter will change
trans-unit.target: The MAC address of the virtual network adapter will change

trans-unit.source: The Processor/CPU ID of the VM will change
trans-unit.target: The Processor/CPU ID of the VM will change

trans-unit.source: The IP configuration of the virtual network adapter will not change as long as the VM is attached to a virtual network and the VM’s IP address is static.
trans-unit.target: The IP configuration of the virtual network adapter will not change as long as the VM is attached to a virtual network and the VM’s IP address is static.

trans-unit.source: None of these behaviors affect Windows Server Active Directory because it has no dependency on the MAC address or Processor/CPU ID, and all Windows Server Active Directory deployments on Azure are recommended to be run on an Azure virtual network as outlined above.
trans-unit.target: None of these behaviors affect Windows Server Active Directory because it has no dependency on the MAC address or Processor/CPU ID, and all Windows Server Active Directory deployments on Azure are recommended to be run on an Azure virtual network as outlined above.

trans-unit.source: Is it safe to virtualize Windows Server Active Directory domain controllers?
trans-unit.target: Is it safe to virtualize Windows Server Active Directory domain controllers?

trans-unit.source: Deploying Windows Server Active Directory DCs on Azure virtual machines is subject to the same guidelines as running DCs on-premises in a virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: Deploying Windows Server Active Directory DCs on Azure virtual machines is subject to the same guidelines as running DCs on-premises in a virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: Running virtualized DCs is a safe practice as long as guidelines for backing up and restoring DCs are followed.
trans-unit.target: Running virtualized DCs is a safe practice as long as guidelines for backing up and restoring DCs are followed.

trans-unit.source: For more information about constraints and guidelines for running virtualized DCs, see [Running Domain Controllers in Hyper-V](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/dd363553).
trans-unit.target: For more information about constraints and guidelines for running virtualized DCs, see [Running Domain Controllers in Hyper-V](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/dd363553).

trans-unit.source: Hypervisors provide or trivialize technologies that can cause problems for many distributed systems, including Windows Server Active Directory.
trans-unit.target: Hypervisors provide or trivialize technologies that can cause problems for many distributed systems, including Windows Server Active Directory.

trans-unit.source: For example, on a physical server, you can clone a disk or use unsupported methods to roll back the state of a server, including using SANs and so on, but doing that on a physical server is much harder than restoring a virtual machine snapshot in a hypervisor.
trans-unit.target: For example, on a physical server, you can clone a disk or use unsupported methods to roll back the state of a server, including using SANs and so on, but doing that on a physical server is much harder than restoring a virtual machine snapshot in a hypervisor.

trans-unit.source: Azure offers functionality that can result in the same undesirable condition.
trans-unit.target: Azure offers functionality that can result in the same undesirable condition.

trans-unit.source: For example, you should not copy VHD files of DCs instead of performing regular backups because restoring them can result in a similar situation to using snapshot restore features.
trans-unit.target: For example, you should not copy VHD files of DCs instead of performing regular backups because restoring them can result in a similar situation to using snapshot restore features.

trans-unit.source: Such rollbacks introduce USN bubbles that can lead to permanently divergent states between DCs.
trans-unit.target: Such rollbacks introduce USN bubbles that can lead to permanently divergent states between DCs.

trans-unit.source: That can cause issues such as:
trans-unit.target: That can cause issues such as:

trans-unit.source: Lingering objects
trans-unit.target: Lingering objects

trans-unit.source: Inconsistent passwords
trans-unit.target: Inconsistent passwords

trans-unit.source: Inconsistent attribute values
trans-unit.target: Inconsistent attribute values

trans-unit.source: Schema mismatches if the schema master is rolled back
trans-unit.target: Schema mismatches if the schema master is rolled back

trans-unit.source: For more information about how DCs are impacted, see [USN and USN Rollback](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/virtual_active_directory_domain_controller_virtualization_hyperv.aspx#usn_and_usn_rollback).
trans-unit.target: For more information about how DCs are impacted, see [USN and USN Rollback](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/virtual_active_directory_domain_controller_virtualization_hyperv.aspx#usn_and_usn_rollback).

trans-unit.source: Beginning with Windows Server 2012, [additional safeguards are built in to AD DS](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/hh831734.aspx).
trans-unit.target: Beginning with Windows Server 2012, [additional safeguards are built in to AD DS](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/hh831734.aspx).

trans-unit.source: These safeguards help protect virtualized domain controllers against the aforementioned problems, as long as the underlying hypervisor platform supports VM-GenerationID.
trans-unit.target: These safeguards help protect virtualized domain controllers against the aforementioned problems, as long as the underlying hypervisor platform supports VM-GenerationID.

trans-unit.source: Azure supports VM-GenerationID, which means that domain controllers that run Windows Server 2012 or later on Azure virtual machines have the additional safeguards.
trans-unit.target: Azure supports VM-GenerationID, which means that domain controllers that run Windows Server 2012 or later on Azure virtual machines have the additional safeguards.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] You should shut down and restart a VM that runs the domain controller role in Azure within the guest operating system instead of using the **Shut Down** option in the Azure classic portal.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] You should shut down and restart a VM that runs the domain controller role in Azure within the guest operating system instead of using the **Shut Down** option in the Azure classic portal.

trans-unit.source: Today, using the classic portal to shut down a VM causes the VM to be deallocated.
trans-unit.target: Today, using the classic portal to shut down a VM causes the VM to be deallocated.

trans-unit.source: A deallocated VM has the advantage of not incurring charges, but it also resets the VM-GenerationID, which is undesirable for a DC.
trans-unit.target: A deallocated VM has the advantage of not incurring charges, but it also resets the VM-GenerationID, which is undesirable for a DC.

trans-unit.target: When the VM-GenerationID is reset, the invocationID of the AD DS database is also reset, the RID pool is discarded, and SYSVOL is marked as non-authoritative.

trans-unit.source: Why deploy Windows Server AD DS on Azure Virtual Machines?
trans-unit.target: Why deploy Windows Server AD DS on Azure Virtual Machines?

trans-unit.source: Many Windows Server AD DS deployment scenarios are well-suited for deployment as VMs on Azure.
trans-unit.target: Many Windows Server AD DS deployment scenarios are well-suited for deployment as VMs on Azure.

trans-unit.source: For example, suppose you have a company in Europe that needs to authenticate users in a remote location in Asia.
trans-unit.target: For example, suppose you have a company in Europe that needs to authenticate users in a remote location in Asia.

trans-unit.source: The company has not previously deployed Windows Server Active Directory DCs in Asia due to the cost to deploy them and limited expertise to manage the servers post-deployment.
trans-unit.target: The company has not previously deployed Windows Server Active Directory DCs in Asia due to the cost to deploy them and limited expertise to manage the servers post-deployment.

trans-unit.source: As a result, authentication requests from Asia are serviced by DCs in Europe with suboptimal results.
trans-unit.target: As a result, authentication requests from Asia are serviced by DCs in Europe with suboptimal results.

trans-unit.source: In this case, you can deploy a DC on a VM that you have specified must be run within the Azure datacenter in Asia.
trans-unit.target: In this case, you can deploy a DC on a VM that you have specified must be run within the Azure datacenter in Asia.

trans-unit.source: Attaching that DC to an Azure virtual network that is connected directly to the remote location will improve authentication performance.
trans-unit.target: Attaching that DC to an Azure virtual network that is connected directly to the remote location will improve authentication performance.

trans-unit.source: Azure is also well-suited as a substitute to otherwise costly disaster recovery (DR) sites.
trans-unit.target: Azure is also well-suited as a substitute to otherwise costly disaster recovery (DR) sites.

trans-unit.source: The relatively low-cost of hosting a small number of domain controllers and a single virtual network on Azure represents an attractive alternative.
trans-unit.target: The relatively low-cost of hosting a small number of domain controllers and a single virtual network on Azure represents an attractive alternative.

trans-unit.source: Finally, you may want to deploy a network application on Azure, such as SharePoint, that requires Windows Server Active Directory but has no dependency on the on-premises network or the corporate Windows Server Active Directory.
trans-unit.target: Finally, you may want to deploy a network application on Azure, such as SharePoint, that requires Windows Server Active Directory but has no dependency on the on-premises network or the corporate Windows Server Active Directory.

trans-unit.source: In this case, deploying an isolated forest on Azure to meet the SharePoint server’s requirements is optimal.
trans-unit.target: In this case, deploying an isolated forest on Azure to meet the SharePoint server’s requirements is optimal.

trans-unit.source: Again, deploying network applications that do require connectivity to the on-premises network and the corporate Active Directory is also supported.
trans-unit.target: Again, deploying network applications that do require connectivity to the on-premises network and the corporate Active Directory is also supported.

trans-unit.source: Global catalog

trans-unit.source: You need to choose whether to install a global catalog (GC).
trans-unit.target: You need to choose whether to install a global catalog (GC).

trans-unit.source: In a single domain forest, you should configure all DCs as global catalog servers.
trans-unit.target: In a single domain forest, you should configure all DCs as global catalog servers.

trans-unit.source: It will not increase costs because there will be no additional replication traffic.
trans-unit.target: It will not increase costs because there will be no additional replication traffic.

trans-unit.source: In a multidomain forest, GCs are necessary to expand Universal Group memberships during the authentication process.
trans-unit.target: In a multidomain forest, GCs are necessary to expand Universal Group memberships during the authentication process.

trans-unit.source: If you do not deploy a GC, workloads on the virtual network that authenticate against a DC on Azure will indirectly generate outbound authentication traffic to query GCs on-premises during each authentication attempt.
trans-unit.target: If you do not deploy a GC, workloads on the virtual network that authenticate against a DC on Azure will indirectly generate outbound authentication traffic to query GCs on-premises during each authentication attempt.

trans-unit.source: The costs associated with GCs are less-predictable because they host every domain (in-part).
trans-unit.target: The costs associated with GCs are less-predictable because they host every domain (in-part).

trans-unit.source: If the workload hosts an Internet-facing service and authenticates users against Windows Server AD DS, the costs could be completely unpredictable.
trans-unit.target: If the workload hosts an Internet-facing service and authenticates users against Windows Server AD DS, the costs could be completely unpredictable.

trans-unit.source: To help reduce GC queries outside of the cloud site during authentication, you can [enable Universal Group Membership Caching](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/cc816928).

trans-unit.source: Placement of the Windows Server AD DS database and SYSVOL
trans-unit.target: Placement of the Windows Server AD DS database and SYSVOL

trans-unit.source: Select where to locate the Windows Server AD DS database, logs, and SYSVOL.
trans-unit.target: Select where to locate the Windows Server AD DS database, logs, and SYSVOL.

trans-unit.source: They must be deployed on Azure Data disks.
trans-unit.target: They must be deployed on Azure Data disks.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] Azure Data disks are constrained to 1 TB.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] Azure Data disks are constrained to 1 TB.

trans-unit.source: Data disk drives do not cache writes by default.
trans-unit.target: Data disk drives do not cache writes by default.

trans-unit.source: Data disk drives that are attached to a VM use write-through caching.
trans-unit.target: Data disk drives that are attached to a VM use write-through caching.

trans-unit.source: Write-through caching makes sure the write is committed to durable Azure storage before the transaction is complete from the perspective of the VM’s operating system.
trans-unit.target: Write-through caching makes sure the write is committed to durable Azure storage before the transaction is complete from the perspective of the VM’s operating system.

trans-unit.source: It provides durability, at the expense of slightly slower writes.
trans-unit.target: It provides durability, at the expense of slightly slower writes.

trans-unit.source: This is important for Windows Server AD DS because write-behind disk-caching invalidates assumptions made by the DC.
trans-unit.target: This is important for Windows Server AD DS because write-behind disk-caching invalidates assumptions made by the DC.

trans-unit.source: Windows Server AD DS attempts to disable write caching but it is up to the disk IO system to honor it.
trans-unit.target: Windows Server AD DS attempts to disable write caching but it is up to the disk IO system to honor it.

trans-unit.source: Failure to disable write caching may, under certain circumstances, introduce USN rollback resulting in lingering objects and other problems.
trans-unit.target: Failure to disable write caching may, under certain circumstances, introduce USN rollback resulting in lingering objects and other problems.

trans-unit.source: As a best practice for virtual DCs, do the following:
trans-unit.target: As a best practice for virtual DCs, do the following:

trans-unit.source: Set the Host Cache Preference setting on the Azure data disk for NONE.
trans-unit.target: Set the Host Cache Preference setting on the Azure data disk for NONE.

trans-unit.source: This prevents issues with write caching for AD DS operations.
trans-unit.target: This prevents issues with write caching for AD DS operations.

trans-unit.source: Store the database, logs, and SYSVOL on the either same data disk or separate data disks.
trans-unit.target: Store the database, logs, and SYSVOL on the either same data disk or separate data disks.

trans-unit.source: Typically, this is a separate disk from the disk used for the operating system itself.
trans-unit.target: Typically, this is a separate disk from the disk used for the operating system itself.

trans-unit.source: The key takeaway is that the Windows Server AD DS database and SYSVOL must not be stored on an Azure Operating System disk type.
trans-unit.target: The key takeaway is that the Windows Server AD DS database and SYSVOL must not be stored on an Azure Operating System disk type.

trans-unit.source: By default, the AD DS installation process installs these components in %systemroot% folder, which is NOT recommended for Azure.
trans-unit.target: By default, the AD DS installation process installs these components in %systemroot% folder, which is NOT recommended for Azure.

trans-unit.source: Federation server configuration
trans-unit.target: Federation server configuration

trans-unit.source: The configuration of Windows Server AD FS federation servers (STSs) depends in part on whether the applications that you want to deploy on Azure need to access resources on your on-premises network.
trans-unit.target: The configuration of Windows Server AD FS federation servers (STSs) depends in part on whether the applications that you want to deploy on Azure need to access resources on your on-premises network.

trans-unit.source: If the applications meet the following criteria, you could deploy the applications in isolation from your on-premises network.
trans-unit.target: If the applications meet the following criteria, you could deploy the applications in isolation from your on-premises network.

trans-unit.source: They accept SAML security tokens
trans-unit.target: They accept SAML security tokens

trans-unit.source: They are exposable to the Internet
trans-unit.target: They are exposable to the Internet

trans-unit.source: They do not access on-premises resources
trans-unit.target: They do not access on-premises resources

trans-unit.source: In this case, configure Windows Server AD FS STSs as follows:
trans-unit.target: In this case, configure Windows Server AD FS STSs as follows:

trans-unit.source: Configure an isolated single-domain forest on Azure.
trans-unit.target: Configure an isolated single-domain forest on Azure.

trans-unit.source: Provide federated access to the forest by configuring a Windows Server AD FS federation server farm.
trans-unit.target: Provide federated access to the forest by configuring a Windows Server AD FS federation server farm.

trans-unit.source: Configure Windows Server AD FS (federation server farm and federation server proxy farm) in the on-premises forest.
trans-unit.target: Configure Windows Server AD FS (federation server farm and federation server proxy farm) in the on-premises forest.

trans-unit.source: Establish a federation trust relationship between the on-premises and Azure instances of Windows Server AD FS.
trans-unit.target: Establish a federation trust relationship between the on-premises and Azure instances of Windows Server AD FS.

trans-unit.source: On the other hand, if the applications require access to on-premises resources, you could configure Windows Server AD FS with the application on Azure as follows:
trans-unit.target: On the other hand, if the applications require access to on-premises resources, you could configure Windows Server AD FS with the application on Azure as follows:

trans-unit.source: Configure connectivity between on-premises networks and Azure.
trans-unit.target: Configure connectivity between on-premises networks and Azure.

trans-unit.source: Configure a Windows Server AD FS federation server farm in the on-premises forest.
trans-unit.target: Configure a Windows Server AD FS federation server farm in the on-premises forest.

trans-unit.source: Configure a Windows Server AD FS federation server proxy farm on Azure.
trans-unit.target: Configure a Windows Server AD FS federation server proxy farm on Azure.

trans-unit.source: This configuration has the advantage of reducing the exposure of on-premises resources, similar to configuring Windows Server AD FS with applications in a perimeter network.
trans-unit.target: This configuration has the advantage of reducing the exposure of on-premises resources, similar to configuring Windows Server AD FS with applications in a perimeter network.

trans-unit.source: Note that in either scenario, you can establish trusts relationships with more identity providers, if business-to-business collaboration is needed.
trans-unit.target: Note that in either scenario, you can establish trusts relationships with more identity providers, if business-to-business collaboration is needed.

trans-unit.source: Cloud services configuration
trans-unit.target: Cloud services configuration

trans-unit.source: Cloud services are necessary if you want to expose a VM directly to the Internet or to expose an Internet-facing load-balanced application.
trans-unit.target: Cloud services are necessary if you want to expose a VM directly to the Internet or to expose an Internet-facing load-balanced application.

trans-unit.source: This is possible because each cloud service offers a single configurable virtual IP address.
trans-unit.target: This is possible because each cloud service offers a single configurable virtual IP address.

trans-unit.source: Federation server requirements for public and private IP addressing (dynamic IP vs. virtual IP)
trans-unit.target: Federation server requirements for public and private IP addressing (dynamic IP vs. virtual IP)

trans-unit.source: Each Azure virtual machine receives a dynamic IP address.
trans-unit.target: Each Azure virtual machine receives a dynamic IP address.

trans-unit.source: A dynamic IP address is a private address accessible only within Azure.
trans-unit.target: A dynamic IP address is a private address accessible only within Azure.

trans-unit.source: In most cases, however, it will be necessary to configure a virtual IP address for your Windows Server AD FS deployments.
trans-unit.target: In most cases, however, it will be necessary to configure a virtual IP address for your Windows Server AD FS deployments.

trans-unit.source: The virtual IP is necessary to expose Windows Server AD FS endpoints to the Internet, and will be used by federated partners and clients for authentication and ongoing management.
trans-unit.target: The virtual IP is necessary to expose Windows Server AD FS endpoints to the Internet, and will be used by federated partners and clients for authentication and ongoing management.

trans-unit.source: A virtual IP address is a property of a cloud service which contains one or more Azure virtual machines.
trans-unit.target: A virtual IP address is a property of a cloud service which contains one or more Azure virtual machines.

trans-unit.source: If the claims-aware application deployed on Azure and Windows Server AD FS are both Internet-facing and share common ports, each will require a virtual IP address of its own and it will therefore be necessary to create one cloud service for the application and a second for Windows Server AD FS.
trans-unit.target: If the claims-aware application deployed on Azure and Windows Server AD FS are both Internet-facing and share common ports, each will require a virtual IP address of its own and it will therefore be necessary to create one cloud service for the application and a second for Windows Server AD FS.
